https://prez.dev/description.@value: The primary purpose for which a borehole was drilled or any secondary purpose that the borehole may acquire during its lifecycle. The vocabulary focuses on drilling purposes within the resources industry, with a focus on terminology as applied in the Geological Survey of Western Australia (GSWA) databases. Some terms covered by jurisdictional legislation are highlighted in the provenance field. Variations in terminology within definitions (i.e. usage of borehole, well and wellbore) stem from usage in different sectors of the resources industry, but for the purpose of this vocabulary are considered to be equivalent. In the context of this vocabulary, the term fluid energy refers to sources such as gas, petroleum and geothermal, as covered by the Petroleum Legislation Amendment Act 2024, and is exclusive of mineral sources of energy (e.g. coal, uranium).

A borehole drilled for the purpose of electrokinetic in-situ leaching (EK-ISL), an emerging mining technology that allows for the recovery of metals from low-permeability ore bodies via boreholes without excavation or permeability enhancement techniques such as fracking. Instead, it uses electrode wells to generate electric fields and induce the transport of charged chemical species that facilitate the selective dissolution, transport and recovery of targeted metals such as copper or gold.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A borehole drilled for the purpose of in-situ leaching (ISL, also called in-situ recovery or ISR) or solution mining, a mining process used to recover minerals (e.g. copper and uranium) through boreholes drilled into a deposit. It works by artificially dissolving minerals occurring naturally in a solid state and pumping the pregnant solution to the surface where the minerals can be recovered.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: A borehole drilled for the purpose of in-situ leaching (ISL, also called in-situ recovery or ISR) or solution mining, a mining process used to recover minerals (e.g. copper and uranium) through boreholes drilled into a deposit. It works by artificially dissolving minerals occurring naturally in a solid state and pumping the pregnant solution to the surface where the minerals can be recovered.
